questionText: Motivation is NOT ________.
multipleChoice: A process that leads to a goal
Something that varies from situation to situation

questionText: Which element of motivation is a measure of intensity or drive?

Maslow's theory is a hierarchy because ________.
Maslow sees food as being on the same level of need as which of the following?
According to Maslow, a person stranded on a desert island would ________ before he or she worried about making weapons.
multipleChoice: Establish his or her status on the island

questionText: An individual who wants to buy a home in a neighborhood with a low crime rate is satisfying which need?
Maslow argued that once a need is substantially satisfied, ________.
multipleChoice: Individuals no longer require that need
That need continues to be the primary motivation of an individual

questionText: Maslow believes that higher-order needs ________.
The key to motivation, according to Maslow, is to identify ________.
multipleChoice: A person's level in the needs hierarchy
A person's most important level in the needs hierarchy

questionText: Maslow's hierarchical model ________.
multipleChoice: Has been validated by a number of studies
Has never been validated by studies
Has been validated by empirical studies
Has been invalidated by intuitive means

questionText: The highest order need in Maslow's hierarchy is ________.
Which one of the following is a lower-order need in Maslow's hierarchy?
________ assumes that employees have little ambition, dislike work, and avoid responsibility.
Theory Y assumes that people inherently ________.
multipleChoice: Want to control their own destiny

questionText: Theory X assumes that people work hard when they ________.
A manager with a Theory X view of human nature would ________.
multipleChoice: Be unlikely to allow workers to work independently
Be likely to let workers coordinate their work

questionText: A manager with a Theory Y view of human nature would be likely ________.
multipleChoice: Not to try to inspire his or her workers
To try to challenge his or her workers
To try to intimidate his or her workers
To monitor his or her workers closely

questionText: Workers with a Theory X point of view would be most likely to respond to ________.
Workers with a Theory Y point of view would be likely to ________.
multipleChoice: Just want to collect a paycheck
Love their job more than the money they make
Avoid work unless rewards were high

questionText: According to Herzberg, which kinds of characteristics are most closely associated with job dissatisfaction?
multipleChoice: Intrinsic things that come from within themselves
Extrinsic things that come from the outside

questionText: According to Herzberg's motivation-hygiene theory, ________ are associated with job satisfaction.
According to Herzberg, which one of the following is considered a motivator?
According to Herzberg, favorable hygiene factors can cause an employee to feel ________.
According to Herzberg, the opposite of the state of being satisfied is ________.
According to Herzberg, when an extremely dissatisfied employee gets an improved salary and working conditions, he or she ________.
multipleChoice: Becomes more motivated and more satisfied
Becomes less motivated and less satisfied
Becomes more dissatisfied, and his or her motivation increases
Becomes less dissatisfied, and his or her motivation is unaffected

questionText: According to Herzberg, what controls satisfaction and motivation?
According to Herzberg, hygiene factors ________.
According to Herzberg, in order to provide employees with job satisfaction, managers should concentrate on ________.
Which one of the following holds that intrinsic factors are related to job satisfaction and extrinsic factors are related to job dissatisfaction?
multipleChoice: McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y

questionText: Herzberg has had the greatest influence on which one of the following?
Which one of the following is true of the three early theories of motivation?
multipleChoice: McGregor focuses on the basic needs of the individual
Both McGregor and Herzberg focus on human nature
McGregor focuses on positive and negative assumptions about human nature

questionText: Which one of the following is true of the three early theories of motivation?
Which one of the following was directly influenced by Herzberg's two-factor theory?
Which three needs are recognized in McClelland's three-needs theory?
Which one of the following suggests that humans have an innate desire for friendly and close interpersonal relationships?
You would expect a successful inventor of a new type of heart valve to have a high ________.
Why are individuals with a high nAch not the most successful managers?
multipleChoice: They are concerned more about effectiveness than efficiency.
They are more focused on organizational goals than their own desires for promotion.
They focus too much on their own goals rather than the goals of others.
They can easily be distracted by trying to build a better mousetrap.

questionText: Successful managers tend to have this more than any other trait.
Successful managers tend to be better at ________.
multipleChoice: Doing their own work than helping others
Identifying their own goals than identifying goals of subordinates
Helping others achieve goals than achieving their own goals

questionText: McClelland's need that has received the most attention and research is the ________.
Zach is what type of manager?
Susan was trying to use what type of Herzberg factors to increase productivity?
Zach was using which type of Herzberg factors to increase productivity levels?
Which is the best summary of goal-setting theory?
multipleChoice: Goals make no difference in performance.
Always make your goals very difficult to reach.
Easy goals make for happier employees.

questionText: Setting goals definitely seems to ________.
In goal-setting theory, which one of the following is the best kind of feedback?
In which kinds of cultures does goal-setting theory work best?
multipleChoice: High power distance, high uncertainty avoidance
Low power distance, high uncertainty avoidance
High power distance, low uncertainty avoidance
Low power distance, low uncertainty avoidance

questionText: Goal-setting tends to do well in ________, where its basic ideas align well with general cultural values.
The job characteristics model (JCM) maintains that ________ is critical to motivating workers.
The JCM contends that meaningful work is ________.
multipleChoice: Considered important and valuable by the worker

questionText: The JCM contends that ________ are required in meaningful work.
multipleChoice: Skill variety, task identity, and task significance

questionText: According to the JCM, which set of three dimensions are required for a high level of motivation among workers?
Autonomy is important in the JCM because it gives the worker ________.
In the JCM, motivation and satisfaction increase when ________.
multipleChoice: The employee feels good about herself.
The employee cares about the task.
The employee feels like she belongs.

questionText: Job enrichment in the JCM seems to work best with people who have ________.
A theory that suggests that employees compare their inputs and outputs from a job to the ratio of relevant others is known as ________.
Equity theory is based primarily on ideas about which of the following?
Equity theory recognizes that individuals are concerned with ________.
multipleChoice: Making enough money to live on
Comparing their rewards to those of others
Justice for all people who work

questionText: Equity theory uses the ratio of outcomes you get from your job to the amount of ________.
multipleChoice: Input you put into your job
Outcome a referent gets from a job
Benefit you get from your job
Compensation you get from your job

questionText: Equity theory compares your own outcomes-to-input ratio to that of ________.
multipleChoice: The input-to-output ratio of another worker
The input-to-output ratio of an idealized worker

questionText: A referent in equity theory refers to which one of the following?
In equity theory, a worker's 'self' category refers to ________.
multipleChoice: The standards and expectations of other workers
Their comparisons to the highest paid worker they know
Their comparisons to the lowest paid worker they know

questionText: Inequity exists when one's own outcomes-to-input ratio ________ that of the referent.
multipleChoice: Is greater than but not less than
Is less than but not greater than
Is greater than or less than

questionText: Equity exists when one's own outcomes-to-input ratio ________ that of the referent.
multipleChoice: Is greater than or less than

questionText: In equity theory, an under-rewarded individual ________ the work he or she does.
Under-rewarded inequity exists when one's own outcomes-to-input ratio ________ that of the referent.
multipleChoice: Is greater than or equal to

questionText: Over-rewarded inequity exists when one's own outcomes-to-inputs ratio ________ that of the referent.
multipleChoice: Is greater than or equal to

questionText: In equity theory, distributive justice is concerned with which one of the following?
multipleChoice: Comparing one individual to an entire system
Comparing output-to-input ratios among large groups

questionText: In equity theory, procedural justice is concerned with which one of the following?
multipleChoice: Determining how fair the system is
Determining how honest one's boss is

questionText: In equity theory, an under-rewarded individual is likely to ________.
multipleChoice: Have high motivation to show his or her value to the organization
Lack motivation because he or she does not receive enough reward for what he or she does
Have just the right motivation to get the job done
Have high motivation due to high self-esteem

questionText: The first variable in expectancy theory involves how much effort a person must exert to ________.
multipleChoice: Attain a certain level of performance
Finish the job in the shortest period of time
Finish the job with the lowest possible standards

questionText: The second variable in expectancy theory requires the worker to ask him- or herself: If I perform at a given level, how likely is it that I will ________?
multipleChoice: Attain the reward or outcome I am looking for
Value a promotion if I get it

questionText: The third variable in expectancy theory requires the worker to ask him- or herself which question?
multipleChoice: How likely am I to attain this outcome?
What do I need to do to attain this outcome?
How important is this outcome to me?
How important is this outcome to the organization I work for?

questionText: In expectancy theory, a person may have the ability to reach a certain goal but lack motivation because ________.
multipleChoice: The person's desire to reach the goal is too strong
The person has no strong desire for the reward

questionText: A key element of expectancy theory might be summarized by saying ________.
multipleChoice: Most people are motivated by money
Everyone is always motivated by fear of failure
Everyone is motivated by the same thing
Different rewards motivate people in different ways

questionText: The key to expectancy theory is that an individual's goals ________.
multipleChoice: Are not too high and not too low
Match the goals of fellow workers and superiors
Match the rewards provided by the organization

questionText: If salespeople in John's company meet their sales goals for the month, they are given an all-expense-paid trip to a Denver Broncos football game. Football is not one of John's favorite sports, and the Denver Broncos are definitely not John's favorite team. John's performance might be influenced by the ________ part of Vroom's expectancy theory.

Katie has just been asked to type up a report in two days using a software program she has never used. Katie wonders if she will be able to get her project accomplished on time and in the format her manager wanted. This is an example of which variable in Vroom's expectancy theory?
Which one of the following theories of motivation is seen as the most comprehensive?
The integrated model for motivation as shown in the chapter reading features the following basic sequence.
multipleChoice: Needs → factors → extrinsic factors → individual goals
Needs → goals → individual effort → organizational goals

questionText: The integrated model for motivation as shown in the chapter reading predicts strong motivation for an individual to perform when the reward is based on ________.
multipleChoice: Seniority or years of service in the organization

questionText: In the integrated model for motivation as shown in the chapter reading, high achievers circumvent the entire sequence of steps for motivation because ________.
multipleChoice: They are motivated by the organization's assessment of their performance
They are internally motivated, not motivated by rewards
They are motivated by rewards only, not by internal factors

questionText: In the integrated model for motivation as shown in the chapter reading, how do reinforcement theory and equity theory figure in?
multipleChoice: Appropriate rewards reinforce a high level of performance.
Underrewarding results in 'hungry' employees who will work harder.
Overrewarding results in 'satisfied' employees who will work harder.
Reinforcement and equity theories do not influence motivation.

questionText: The JCM is seen in the integrated model of motivation in that jobs that are designed around the five JCM dimensions ________.
multipleChoice: Increase motivation because workers enjoy the work and autonomy they provide
Decrease motivation because the work is too easy to complete and the autonomy lacks structure
Increase motivation by applying pressure to employees
Decrease motivation by giving employees too much autonomy

questionText: To increase the motivation through enrichment, Acme decides to increase the meaningfulness of the work. This might be done by ________.
Most jobs at Acme were redesigned to allow the employees to complete a whole and identifiable piece of work. This fits ________, a core dimension of the job characteristics model.
Acme managers explained how important their product was to the world economy. Which core dimension in the job characteristics model is this?
In today's diverse workforce, which factor do managers need to focus on most to maximize motivation?
Which one of the following describes the effect of flexible work arrangements on employees?
multipleChoice: A drastic decrease in job satisfaction
A small decrease in job satisfaction
A sharp increase in job satisfaction

questionText: Which one of the following is thought to best motivate professionals?
multipleChoice: Status and power within the organization
Short hours and good working conditions

questionText: Which one of the following is NOT recognized as a way to motivate contingent workers?
multipleChoice: Promise of permanent employment in the future
Opportunity to work alongside permanent employees

questionText: What is a potential disadvantage of telecommuting?
multipleChoice: Lack of time for personal or family needs
Job satisfaction may decrease based on the number of hours spent telecommuting.

questionText: Which one of the following is NOT a common way that employee recognition programs recognize worker achievements?
Compensation plans based on employee output or productivity are referred to as ________.
During tough economic times, managers find that ________ work(s) best for motivating employees.
multipleChoice: De-emphasizing how employees work is tied to performance
Promotions in job status without increased pay
